skill.name: expo-dev-client
skill.description: Build and distribute Expo development clients locally or via TestFlight
skill.summary: Build and distribute Expo development clients for testing custom native code
skill.author: expo

security_audit.summary: All 38 static findings evaluated as false positives. The skill contains legitimate documentation for Expo EAS CLI commands and standard development workflows. No malicious patterns, command injection vectors, or data exfiltration detected.

high_findings.title: External Commands Documentation
high_findings.description: The skill contains examples of EAS CLI and development tool commands. These are legitimate documentation examples for building Expo development clients.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: All commands are hardcoded EAS CLI examples with no user input injection. These are standard Expo development workflow documentation.

content.value_statement: Expo Go does not support custom native code. This skill helps you build custom development clients for testing native modules, widgets, and app extensions on physical devices.
actual_capabilities: Generate EAS Build configuration for development clients
Build iOS development clients for TestFlight distribution
Build iOS and Android development clients locally
Install development clients on simulators and physical devices
Troubleshoot common build and signing issues
Configure development profiles for different platforms
limitations: Does not create new Expo projects from scratch
Does not handle Apple Developer program setup or certificates
Does not modify existing native code in your project
Requires an active Expo account and EAS CLI

use_cases.title: Test custom native modules
use_cases.description: Create a development client to test third-party native modules that are not supported in Expo Go. Use this when you need to iterate on native code changes.
use_cases.target_user: React Native developers adding custom native functionality

use_cases.title: Build for iOS widgets and extensions
use_cases.description: Create a development client that supports Apple widgets, app clips, and extensions. Required for testing iOS-specific platform features.
use_cases.target_user: iOS developers building Apple platform extensions

use_cases.title: Distribute test builds via TestFlight
use_cases.description: Build a development client and submit it to TestFlight for QA testing on physical devices without App Store review.

prompt_templates.title: Quick development client setup
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to create a development client for my Expo project. My app uses custom native code that does not work in Expo Go. Help me set up the eas.json configuration and build a development client for iOS.
prompt_templates.scenario: Setting up EAS configuration for the first time

prompt_templates.title: Build for TestFlight
prompt_templates.prompt: Build and submit my iOS development client to TestFlight so my QA team can test on physical devices. What commands do I need to run and what happens after the build is ready?
prompt_templates.scenario: Distributing test builds to external testers

prompt_templates.title: Local build troubleshooting
prompt_templates.prompt: My local iOS build is failing with signing errors. Help me diagnose the issue and configure my credentials correctly using eas credentials.

prompt_templates.title: Android development build
prompt_templates.prompt: Build an Android development client locally. I want to install it on a physical device for testing. Walk me through the process from eas.json configuration to adb installation.

output_examples.input: How do I create a development client for my Expo app that uses a custom native module?
output: You need a development client when your app requires custom native code. Here's the process:
1. Configure eas.json with a development profile:
Download from TestFlight or install the local .ipa/.apk file on your device.

output_examples.input: My build is failing with signing errors. What should I do?
output: Run 'eas credentials' to configure your Apple signing credentials. This will help you:
- Verify your Apple Developer account is connected
- Set up the correct team ID and bundle identifier
- Resolve certificate and provisioning profile issues
If you need to clear a corrupted build cache, run:

best_practices: Start with Expo Go to validate your JavaScript code before building a development client
Use TestFlight distribution for team testing to avoid device-side installation complexity
Increment build numbers automatically using 'autoIncrement: true' in eas.json
anti_patterns: Creating a development client when Expo Go would suffice
Skipping the eas credentials configuration when build errors occur
Using local builds for team distribution instead of TestFlight

faq.question: When should I use a development client instead of Expo Go?
faq.answer: Use a development client when your app requires custom native code, such as local Expo modules, Apple widgets, app clips, extensions, or third-party native modules not supported by Expo Go.

faq.question: How do I install a local iOS build on my device?
faq.answer: Extract the build with 'tar -xzf build-*.tar.gz', then use Xcode Devices window to install the .app file, or use 'ideviceinstaller -i build.ipa' for physical devices.

faq.question: Can I build for both iOS and Android in one command?
faq.answer: Yes. Run 'eas build --profile development' without specifying a platform to build for both iOS and Android simultaneously.

faq.question: How do I check the status of my EAS build?
faq.answer: Use 'eas build:list' to see recent builds and 'eas build:view' for detailed information about a specific build.

faq.question: What is the difference between local and cloud builds?
faq.answer: Cloud builds run on EAS infrastructure and support TestFlight submission. Local builds run on your machine, require Xcode/Android Studio, and produce files you install manually.

faq.question: How do I connect the dev client to my local Metro bundler?
faq.answer: Run 'npx expo start --dev-client' to start the bundler. The dev client will show a QR code scanner or allow you to enter your local server URL manually.
